description: From Middle English ametist, from Old French ametiste (French améthyste), from Ancient Greek ἀμέθυστος (améthustos, “not drunk”), from ἀ- (a-, “not”) + μεθύω (methúō, “I am drunk”), from μέθυ (méthu, “wine”). The Greeks believed that the amethyst prevented intoxication.

adjectives.description: amethyst (comparative more amethyst, superlative most amethyst)

entries.meaning: Having a colour similar to that of the gemstone
A transparent purple variety of quartz, used as a gemstone.
(heraldry) The tincture purpure, when emblazoning the arms of the English nobility.
